p: In total 71 resident species were recorded (Table A1). Besides I. glandulifera, Lamium argentatum occurring in two pairs of plots was the only alien plant species. In the control treatments, resident species number ranged from 2 to 16 per 1 m 2 and did not differ between invaded and uninvaded plots and between habitats, and likewise the Shannon index did not differ (Figure 3a). Total biomass and height of the resident vegetation in contrast were significantly higher in uninvaded plots than in invaded ones, biomass by about 124 g and vegetation height by almost 50 cm. Both were lower in alder forests than in meadows. However, for vegetation height, this difference was not significant because of a high variation between study sites (mixed‐effect model). Species composition and abundance differed between invaded and uninvaded plots and also between habitats (Table 1, Figure 4). For example, Galeopsis tetrahit and Cardamine amara tend to have more biomass in invaded control plots, while for Carex acutiformis, Aegopodium podagraria, and Chaerophyllum hirsutum this is the case in uninvaded ones. Cirsium oleraceum, Ajuga reptans and Carex brizoides only occurred in uninvaded control plots. Comparing habitats regarding their species composition Geranium palustre, Carex acutiformis, and Mentha longifolia, for example, were specific to meadows, while Circaea lutetiana, Dryopteris carthusiana, Chrysosplenium oppositifolium, and Ch. alternifolium to forests. The common species Urtica dioica, Galium aparine, Filipendula ulmaria, Phalaris arundinacea, Stellaria nemorum, Agrostis caninus, Galeopsis tetrahit, Aegopodium podagraria, and Chaerophyllum hirsutum occurred consistently across both habitats although biomass could vary.
